lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about ostriches and find key details such as body parts and what they can or can’t do.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read the text aloud. Ask: “What can ostriches do?” “What body part is strong?” Students underline key info.
stretchStrategies: ❝True or Silly?❞ – After reading about the ostrich, give students statements using body part language (e.g., “Ostriches have big arms.”). Students decide if it’s true or silly, and explain why using “It’s got…”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write CVC words (e.g., ham, jam, web).
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say and trace CVC words like “jam,” “ham,” “web.” Students repeat and write them, matching to pictures.
stretchStrategies: ❝True or Silly?❞ – After reading about the ostrich, give students statements using body part language (e.g., “Ostriches have big arms.”). Students decide if it’s true or silly, and explain why using “It’s got…”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can describe what ostriches look like and say what they can or can’t do.
supportStrategies: (Science) Show ostrich images. Ask: “Is it fast?” “Can it fly?” Students answer yes/no with gestures and simple sentences.
stretchStrategies: ❝True or Silly?❞ – After reading about the ostrich, give students statements using body part language (e.g., “Ostriches have big arms.”). Students decide if it’s true or silly, and explain why using “It’s got…”

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
